titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Darrin Zammit Lupi photojournalism archive, 2004-2017 RL.11613
titlestmt.author: M. Farrell; Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-02-19 19:55:02 UTC.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Darrin Zammit Lupi is a photojournalist based in Malta. This archive comprises two bodies of documentary work. The earlier project, Malta Detention, consists of color photographs, taken by Lupi from 2004-2013, of African migrants and asylum seekers in Malta detention camps. In these camps, the migrants faced many months in limbo, waiting for the outcome of their journey and holding protests about their treatment. This series includes over 1800 digital files containing low-resolution images, contact sheets, and a group of news articles. The second project, On Board the MV Aquarius, comprises color photographs and supporting image files, documents, data, videos, news stories, and interviews compiled by Lupi in December, 2017, while on board the Aquarius, a migrant search and rescue ship operated by the non-profit organizations SOS Méditerranée and Médecins sans frontières; while there, he documented the rescue of 320 migrants in the Mediterranean Sea, and their safe arrival in Pozzallo, Sicily. All prints measure 20x24 inches. Acquired as part of the Human Rights Archive at Duke University.
did.physdesc: 40 color photographic prints; 5033 digital files (4681 jpeg, 257 tiff, 68 png, 11 mp4, 10 pdf, 2 doc, 1 xls, 1 VLC, 2 txt)
did.materialspec: Materials are chiefly in English, with a few in French, Italian, Korean, Spanish, and other languages.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Darrin Zammit Lupi was born in Malta in 1968. He started his photography career with The Malta Independent in 1992, but decided to turn freelance shortly afterwards. He has documented conditions in Albania and the former Yugoslavia, the South-East Asia tsunami tragedy, the refugee crisis during the war in Kosovo, the earthquake in L'Aquila, Italy, and the war in Libya.

He has won the Malta Journalism Awards for Press Photography seven times and the Sport Photography award three times, as well as a special award for Creativity in Photojournalism. The Societies for Photographers in the UK named him Overall Photographer of the Year for 2016, Media Photographer of the Year for 2013, Documentary Photographer of the Year for 2014, and Street Photographer of the Year for 2016.

His work for Reuters has been published in newspapers, magazines, books and online worldwide. He holds a Masters Degree with Distinction in Photojournalism and Documentary Photography from the University of the Arts, London.

In late 2014, he published his book Isle Landers, covering a decade's work on irregular immigration and asylum seekers in the Mediterranean. Work from that collection has been exhibited in Malta, France, Luxembourg, and Australia.

Some of his works form part of the permanent collection at the National Museum of Fine Arts in Malta, private collections in other countries, and the Human Rights Archive at Duke University's David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.
Source: adapted from photographer's website, accessed Nov. 15, 2019)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection contains electronic records that must be requested through the collection guide and accessed in the Rubenstein Library reading room. Note: Tiff images from the "On Board the Aquarius" project are immediately available through links in this collection guide.
Please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.
Images may only be used for educational, non-commercial purposes; any other use requires the photographer's permission.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Darrin Zammit Lupi photojournalism archive was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2018 and 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Darrin Zammit Lupi photojournalism archive, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed and encoded by Paula Jeannet and M. Farrell, September 2018 and November 2019-January 2020.
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2018-0034, 2019-0075.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Darrin Zammit Lupi photojournalism archive comprises two bodies of documentary work. The earlier project, Malta Detention, consists of color photographs, taken by Zammit Lupi from 2004-2013, of African migrants and asylum seekers in Malta detention camps. In these camps, the migrants faced many months in limbo, waiting for the outcome of their journey and holding protests about their treatment. This series includes over 1800 digital files containing low-resolution images, contact sheets, and a group of news articles. The second project, On Board the MV Aquarius, comprises 20 color photographs and over 4000 supporting image files, documents, data, videos, news stories, and interviews compiled by Lupi in December, 2017, while on board the Aquarius, a migrant search and rescue ship operated by the non-profit organizations SOS Méditerranée and Médecins sans frontières; while there, he documented the rescue of 320 migrants on boats in the Mediterranean Sea, and their safe arrival in Pozzallo, Sicily. All prints measure 20x24 inches.

Electronic resources related to these two projects include almost 5000 born-digital image files in tiff, jpeg, and png formats. These include digital contact sheets and low-resolution files, as well as full color tiffs from which images were chosen for printing. Note: Tiff images from the "On Board the Aquarius" project are available through links in this collection guide. All other electronic files must be requested in advance and are accessible only onsite in the library reading room.

The 2017 Aquarius migrant rescue project include many additional related digital files: these include nine videos in mp4 format, taken by Darrin Zammit Lupi. Five document the MV Aquarius rescue and a transfer of refugees from another ship; three are interviews with an Italian rescuer and two migrants; and one is a news report video narrated by Lupi. The interviews describe conditions in detention centers in Libya and on board the escape boats.

Other supporting documents and digital content for the 2017 Aquarius migrant project comprise press releases in English, French, Spanish, Italian, Korean, and other languages; shot lists; demographic data summarizing the makeup of the migrants on board the rescue ship; screen shots of Reuters social media posts relating to this story, featuring Zammit Lupi's images; and scans of a 17-page journal kept by Zammit Lupi while aboard the rescue ship.
All image titles, captions, and other descriptions have been taken from the originals.

physdesc.extent: 3210 files (110 tiff, 3035 jpg, 46 png, 11 mp4, 3 pdf, 2 doc, 1 VLC, 1 txt, and 1 xls)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This body of work comprises several thousand documentary images and supporting documents, data, videos, news stories, and interviews from the project On Board the MV Aquarius, December 2017, by photojournalist Darrin Zammit Lupi, on assignment for the Reuters news agency. While on board the Aquarius, a migrant search and rescue ship operated by the non-profit organizations SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans frontières, Zammit Lupi witnessed and documented the rescue of 320 migrants in the central Mediterranean, and their safe arrival in Pozzallo, Sicily.

Image formats include 110 digital tff files, digital contact sheets, jpeg image files, mp4 video files, and 20 color inkjet photographic prints measuring 20x 24 inches. There are also social media posts (screen shots), logs, scripts, shotlists, and data sheets. Video interviews with several immigrants and one ship staff describe conditions in detention centers in Libya and on board the boats. Also includes scans of 17-page journal kept by Zammit Lupi while aboard the rescue ship.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Most of the files and prints are arranged according to the timeline of events as photographed by Zammit Lupi.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection contains electronic records that must be requested through the collection guide and accessed in the Rubenstein Library reading room. Note: tiff images are immediately accessible through links in this collection guide.
Please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Crew members of MV Aquarius, a migrant search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, wait at their muster station during a firefighting drill, as the ship makes its way towards the search and rescue zone in the central Mediterranean off the coast of Libya, December 15, 2017. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A migrant on the MV Aquarius, a search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, calls out to migrants on the MV Open Arms, the search and rescue ship of Proactiva Open Arms, before a mid-sea transfer of migrants in the central Mediterranean off the coast of Libya, December 16, 2017. 154 migrants were transferred to the Aquarius from Open Arms, bringing the total on board to 320. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprises 20 color inkjet prints, selected by the photographer Darrin Zammit Lupi from the thousands of digital photographs he took while on board an Italian rescue ship in the Mediterranean. The prints measure approximately 20x24 inches.

Digital images of these prints are immediately available in this collection guide, via links in the tiffs format series. There are also low-resolution images and contact sheets with related images available; these are only accessible onsite, in the Rubenstein Library reading room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Migrants on a rubber dinghy are rescued by the crew of MV Aquarius, a search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, in the central Mediterranean 69 nautical miles off the coast of Libya, December 15, 2017. 166 migrants were rescued and brought to the Aquarius in a joint operation with the Italian Navy frigate "Rizzo". Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Migrants on a rubber dinghy await rescue by the crew of MV Aquarius, a search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, in the central Mediterranean 69 nautical miles off the coast of Libya, December 15, 2017. 166 migrants were rescued and brought to the Aquarius in a joint operation with the Italian Navy frigate "Rizzo". Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A rescue boat from the Italian Navy frigate Rizzo brings migrants rescued from a rubber dinghy to the MV Aquarius, a search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, in the central Mediterranean 69 nautical miles off the coast of Libya, December 15, 2017. 166 migrants were rescued and brought to the Aquarius in a joint operation with the Italian Navy frigate "Rizzo". Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Migrants embrace on the deck of of MV Aquarius, a search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, after being rescued in the central Mediterranean 69 nautical miles off the coast of Libya, December 15, 2017. 166 migrants were rescued and brought to the Aquarius in a joint operation with the Italian Navy frigate "Rizzo". Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Migrants queue to be registered on MV Aquarius, a search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, after being rescued in the central Mediterranean 69 nautical miles off the coast of Libya, December 15, 2017. 166 migrants were rescued and brought to the Aquarius in a joint operation with the Italian Navy frigate "Rizzo". Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Migrants talk on the MV Aquarius, a search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, the morning after being rescued in the central Mediterranean off the coast of Libya, December 16, 2017. 166 migrants were rescued and brought to the Aquarius in a joint operation with the Italian Navy frigate "Rizzo". Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Migrants arrive on the MV Aquarius, a search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, after a mid-sea transfer from MV Open Arms, the search and rescue ship of Proactiva Open Arms, in the central Mediterranean off the coast of Libya, December 16, 2017. 154 migrants were transferred to the Aquarius from Open Arms, bringing the total on board to 320. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A crew member of MV Open Arms, the search and rescue ship of Proactiva Open Arms, carries a migrant baby before passing it to crew members of MV Aquarius, a search and rescue ship run in partnership between SOS Méditeranée and Médecins sans Frontières, during a mid-sea transfer of migrants in the central Mediterranean off the coast of Libya, December 16, 2017. 154 migrants were transferred to the Aquarius from Open Arms, bringing the total on board to 320. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series contains electronic records that must be requested through the collection guide and accessed in the Rubenstein Library reading room. Note: tiff images are immediately accessible through links in this collection guide.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes scans from Zammit Lupi's 16-page journal, and an Excel data file on the migrants, listing gender, age, and origin. A Word document lists news sources that reposted the Reuter's reports by Zammit Lupi, including Italian, French, Spanish, Czech, Arabic, Korean, Dutch, Turkish, and Israeli news outlets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The color photographs in this series were taken by photojournalist Darrin Zammit Lupi over a period of nine years in detention camps for undocumented migrants near Valletta, the capital city of Malta. The images document migrants, chiefly from West Africa and Sub-Saharan regions, as they wait, sometimes for 18 months, for a decision on their status. There are close-up portraits of individuals, as well as group shots; settings include interiors as well as outside areas. There are photographs of immigrants protesting conditions in the camps and a few of immigrants on their way to trials in court. One sequence records Jacques Barrot, European Commissioner, visiting a detention center and meeting with protesters. All prints measure approximately 20x24 inches.

Electronic records (1821 files) also form an important part of this series. All images are in color. They include 147 tiff files; 1646 low-resolution jpegs from which the larger images were selected; 20 png images of contact sheets; and eight pdfs of Times of Malta newspaper articles on migrant detention camps, featuring Lupi's photographic work. The tiff images are immediately available through links in this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An Armed Forces of Malta soldier sits with Illegal immigrants under a tree at the detention centre at Safi barracks in Safi, outside Valletta, July 25, 2004. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Illegal immigrants watch visiting journalists as banners demanding their freedom hang at a detention centre in the Armed Forces of Malta Safi barracks, outside Valletta, March 23, 2006. Around 1,000 illegal immigrants are currently in detention in Malta. The Malta government insists the immigrants must be held in detention because their large numbers may cause problems to the economy, while the immigrants say they never intended to come to Malta in the first place and want to be allowed to go to Italy. A delegation of European Members of Parliament is visiting Malta in the coming days to draw up a report on illegal immigration. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An African would-be immigrant sleeps on a mattress in an enclosed compound at the Safi detention centre outside Valletta July 15, 2008. Around 1,500 illegal immigrants are currently held in detention in Malta for periods of up to 18 months. Though their intention was to reach Italy, most found themselves in Malta when they were rescued by the Maltese Armed Forces when they found themselves in difficulties while on their way to reach European soil from Africa. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handcuffed African irregular immigrants walk out of a court in Valletta August 17, 2011. Twenty-three immigrants were charged with starting a riot, causing damage and injuring police officers in a disturbance at a detention camp on Tuesday. The immigrants, who all arrived from Libya over the last six months, rioted after being told that their request for humanitarian protection had been refused, according to local media. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

According to an analysis by the European Union border control agency Frontex, the Libyan conflict has had a negative effect on Malta in terms of migration. Malta has been warned to expect high numbers of irregular immigrants to continue to flow out of Libya as the new government there remains focused on other priorities, local media reported. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: African immigrants hold posters showing Mamadou Kamara of Mali, who was killed while being held in detention by Maltese authorities during a demonstration against racism, in Valletta July 11, 2012. Two soldiers, who stand accused of murdering the Mali immigrant in a Detention Service van in June, were granted bail by the court earlier this week after hearing two days of evidence, according to local media. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An African illegal immigrant helps with the food distribution at the Safi detention centre in Safi, outside Valletta, July 17, 2012. Illegal immigrants arriving on the island of Malta are detained for up to 18 months, a policy which the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) has said urgently needs a comprehensive review following the death of a Malian immigrant while in custody last month, according to local media. There are currently around 1000 immigrants being held in detention, according to government officials. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.p: African illegal immigrants mill around at the Safi detention centre in Safi, outside Valletta, July 17, 2012. There are currently around 1000 immigrants being held in detention, according to government officials. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bridget Ezukuse, a Nigerian newly-arrived immigrant whose husband drowned before he could be rescued on Wednesday sits crying in a common room at the Lyster Barracks detention centre in Hal Far, outside Valletta, August 18, 2012. Some 1200 immigrants have landed on the Mediterranean island of Malta since January. They face mandatory detention which can last for 18 months but figures show nearly half are allowed out sooner, following the granting of refugee status or humanitarian protection, according to official sources. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

Italy will seek an overhaul of European asylum policies and emergency action to handle a crisis that has seen tens of thousands of African migrants arrive in Sicily and Malta and hundreds of deaths, Prime Minister Enrico Letta said on Tuesday. Photo: Darrin Zammit Lupi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A 29-year-old Eritrean migrant stands against a fence at the Safi barracks detention centre for immigrants, which currently holds around 650 detainees, in Safi, outside Valletta, October 22, 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: African illegal immigrants mill around at the Safi detention centre in Safi, outside Valletta, July 17, 2012. Illegal immigrants arriving on the island of Malta are detained for up to 18 months, a policy which the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) has said urgently needs a comprehensive review following the death of a Malian immigrant while in custody last month, according to local media. There are currently around 1000 immigrants being held in detention, according to government officials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An Ethiopian immigrant carries her two-week old child at the Lyster Detention Centre in Hal Far, outside Valletta April 19, 2011. Around 1,100 African immigrants fleeing the violence in Libya have arrived in Malta over the past month, according to officials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Wondering what it's like out there

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An African would-be immigrant holds onto a perimeter fence in an enclosed compound at the Safi detention centre outside Valletta July 15, 2008. Around 1,500 illegal immigrants are currently held in detention in Malta for periods of up to 18 months. Though their intention was to reach Italy, most found themselves in Malta when they were rescued by the Maltese Armed Forces when they found themselves in difficulties while on their way to reach European soil from Africa.

did.unittitle: Despairing immigrant at Lyster barracks Safi detention centre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An illegal immigrant cries as he hangs onto a perimeter fence at a detention centre in the Armed Forces of Malta Lyster barracks, outside Valletta, March 23, 2006. Around 1,000 illegal immigrants are currently in detention in Malta. The Malta government insists the immigrants must be held in detention because their large numbers may cause problems to the economy, while the immigrants say they never intended to come to Malta in the first place and want to be allowed to go to Italy. A delegation of European Members of Parliament is visiting Malta in the coming days to draw up a report on illegal immigration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An old soccer ball is caught in a razor wire fence at the Lyster barracks detention centre for immigrants, which currently holds around 250 detainees, in Hal Far, outside Valletta July 19, 2013. Would-be immigrants who land in Malta face mandatory detention which can last for 18 months but figures show nearly half are allowed out sooner, following the granting of refugee status or humanitarian protection, according to official sources.

did.unittitle: Watching from behind the fence at Safi detention centre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Would-be immigrants walk in a courtyard at the Safi barracks detention centre for immigrants, which currently holds around 600 detainees, in Safi, outside Valletta July 19, 2013. Would-be immigrants who land in Malta face mandatory detention which can last for 18 months but figures show nearly half are allowed out sooner, following the granting of refugee status or humanitarian protection, according to official sources. Malta will be given concrete assistance by the European Commission to return failed asylum seekers to their country of origin, the government has announced.

did.unittitle: Photo caption: Somali asylum seekers who fled Libya by boat and were rescued at sea by the Armed Forces of Malta and an Italian cargo ship last weekend are seen here at Lyster Detention Centre
Photo caption: Iyahen Sunday / Bridget Ezukuse arriving at Haywharf in the early hours of Thursday after being rescued at sea.
Photo caption: Behind bars... Aliu Mega
Photo caption: 'Please help us...' European Commissioner Jacques Barrot meeting a group of protesters at Lyster Barracks yesterday
Photo caption: An immigrant looks out of the police van as he is taken to prison after facing charges in court

Photo caption: In a centre where religions co-exist, one wall resembles a Christian shrine with pictures of Jesus, the Virgin Mary and a crucifix / Migrants with nothing to do whileaway their time at the Safi detention centre.

Photo caption: Smiles at the detention centre: A toddler seems to be enjoying the friendly tease by one of the immigrants being detained in Ħal Far. / A woman who fled Libya and gave birth in Malta shows off her newborn child from behind the bars at Ħal Far detention centre.
Photo caption: Boredom and uncertainty about their future are among the burdens that illegal immigrants face when held in detention centres as they await the outcome of their application for asylum.
